FARM CHEESE-MAKING J. H. Frandsen and T. Thorson A large amount of food material goes to waste every year in skim milk and buttermilk. In making butter all the fat is removed from the milk, leaving the protein or muscle-building substance in the skim milk or buttermilk. From the standpoint of supplying the necessary food to the body, this material is more valuable than the fat alone, since butter contains less than half the food material present in the milk. A great deal of food that is now used for animal feeding could be made into products for human use, by making the milk or milk products into cheese. While a great deal more skim milk could profitably be used both as a beverage and in cooking, a great deal more could be used in making cheese. Several kinds of cheese can be made from skim milk and buttermilk, while others can be made from whole milk. In either case, more of the food value of milk is conserved for human use than when only the fat is used. COMPOSITION AND FOOD VALUE OF CHEESE The materials found in milk are of two classes, those that make up the cheese and those that go into the whey. The cheese - forming materials are fat and casein. The whey-forming materials include the water, milk sugar, albumen, and mineral matter. Some water is retained in the cheese and is therefore one of the cheese-forming materials also. Thus, cheese is composed almost entirely of casein, butter fat, and water. So much importance has been attached to the percentage of butter fat in milk and other dairy products that the real value of the other materials found in milk is usually underestimated and frequently entirely overlooked. This is a mistake, since casein, which is the principal protein compound of milk and also the principal constituent of cheese, is one of the cheapest forms of muscle-building material. In general, foods that are high in protein are high in price. Protein is usually supplied by meat in the diet of most persons. A pound of cheese will supply twice as much protein as a pound of the very best meat. For that reason it can be used as a substitute for meat to a considerable extent. In Farmers' Bulletin No. 487 by the United States Department of Agriculture), "The Economical Use of Cheese in the Diet," the following statement is made: "From the standpoint of the housekeeper cheese is of importance because of its high nutritive value, particularly its high percentage of protein or muscle-forming materials, because of the ease with

4 Extension Bulletin No. 47, College of Agriculture which it can be kept and prepared for the table and the great variety of ways in which it can be served." As a food, cheese has always stood high in European countries, taking the place of meat to a large extent. Cheese being rich in protein logically replaces such foods as meat and eggs, as is shown by the following table: TABLE 1 — The average composition of cheese and some other common foods as purchased 1 Food Carbo- Mineral Fuel value material Refuse | Water Protein Fat hydrates matter per pound One of the greatest objections to the more general use of cheese is that it gives rise to certain physiological disturbances when it is eaten in very large quantities. The United States Department of Agriculture has investigated this matter. Its findings are summarized in the following statement quoted from Fanners' Bulletin No. 487: "Extensive studies have been carried on as a part of the Department's nutrition investigation of the food value, thoroness of digestibility, ease of digestion, physiolog - ical effect, and special character of cheese as food, as well as methods of preparing it for the table. The conclusion drawn from this extended study is, in brief, that cheese properly pre - pared and used is not generally a cause of physiological disturb - ances and that it may be easily introduced into the bill of fare in such quantities as to serve as the chief source of nitrogenous (muscle-building) food and may be made a substitute of other nitrogenous foods when such a substitution is desired." In Hutchinson's "Food and Dietetics" the following statement is made: "The larger the lumps of cheese that reach the stomach the slower will the digestive juices act upon it. Hence, the im - portance of reducing the cheese to a state of fine division before •From Fanners' Bulletin No. 487, United States Department of Agriculture. Per cent Per cent Per cent Per cent Per cent :heese 34.2 25.2 33.7 I 2.4 Jeef of av. comp. 18.6 60.5 15.2 15.5 'orter- house.. 12.7 52.4 i 19.1 i Dried beef 53.7 26.4 6.9 Sggs 11.2 65.5 13.1 9.3 Milk 87.0 3.3 4.0 5.0 irt*d 35.3 9.2 1.3 53.1 'otatoea. 20.0 62.6 1.8 .1 14.7 Percent* 3.8 .7 .8 8.9 .9 .7 1.1 .8 Calories 1,950 935 l.lio 790 635 310 1,215 295

Farm Cheese-Making 5 ii is swallowed. This may be done by careful mastication, but a better plan is to break up the cheese before it is eaten at all. This may be done by grating, but a better way is to dissolve the cheese and then mix it thru some other form of food. If the cheese is first grated or finely chopped and some milk and eggs added, a very savory and exceedingly nutritious pudding or fondu may be prepared at a very small cost. If cheese is ever to take the place it ought to have as a cheap and convenient form of protein food, some such method must be employed, for it is the difficulty with which cheese is digested that renders it impossible food to some persons." So much of the cheese now on the market is made in factories equipped with modern apparatus that many persons are led to believe that cheese is a factory product which can not be made without expensive equipment. As a matter of fact, cheese has been made for some centuries in the farm dairies of the Old World. It is not the purpose of this bulletin to discuss the relative merits of farm and factory dairy systems but to supply information in regard to the manufacture of cheese on the farm. Some of these cheeses are very easily made with utensils found in every home, while others are a little more difficult; but with a little experience, any of the cheeses here described can be made without much difficulty. COTTAGE CHEESE In every pound of cottage cheese there is about one-fifth of a pound of protein, nearly all of which is digestible. A pound of cottage cheese daily would supply all the protein required by the ordinary adult engaged in a sedentary occupation. The United States Department of Agriculture states that cottage cheese is much cheaper than most meats in supplying protein for the diet. For protein, one pound of cottage cheese equals: 1.27 pounds sirloin steak 1.00 pound round steak 1.37 pounds chuck rib beef 1.46 pounds fresh ham 1.44 pounds smoked ham 1.58 pounds loin pork chop 1.31 pounds hind leg of lamb 1.37 pounds breast of veal In addition to protein, energy for performing body work must be supplied by food. Furthermore, as a source of energy, cottage cheese is cheaper than most meats at present prices. On the basis of energy supplied, one pound of cottage cheese equals: 8J ounces sirloin steak 11 J ounces round steak 111 ounces chuck rib beef 10 J ounces fowl 5 ounces smoked ham 6 ounces loin pork chop 7 J ounces hind leg of lamb 12 1 ounces breast of veal 5} ounces fresh ham

Farm Chreae-M (iking 7 added to the raw milk without heating it and set away in a warm place to sour. From this point, the procew in the name aa that already described. Cottage cheese is sometimes put up in pound prints quite the same as butter. A more common way, however, when put - ting it up for market, in to put it in pasteboard boxes. Oyster pails are also sometimes used. Cottage cheese will sell for from 10 cents to 20 cents a pound, depending upon the quality of the cheese and the market. It can be served in a great variety of ways, Quite often It is eaten without any further preparation. It is delirious served with cream and sugar. It can also be made Into a salad. Farmers' Hulletln No. 4K7 gives a large number of ways In which It can be served. BUTTERMILK CHKMft Ituttermilk cheese Is quite similar In appearance and flavor to cottage cheese. It Is smooth and fine grained.
